awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Capturing atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) via water electrolysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be in the development of an economically viable process that can help mitigate and reverse climate change by pulling carbon dioxide (CO2) from the air and using it to make durable polymers used in items that surround us every day. There is increasing global pressure to end emissions-intensive, fossil fuel-based operations. However, society has a extensive infrastructure that uses hydrocarbon as fuels as well as in plastics and other polymers. The proposed system will be used to manufacture useful hydrocarbon materials using carbon dioxide captured from air and hydrogen split from water. This technology represents a new pathway for meeting global demand for hydrocarbons without relying on fossil fuels, which may result not only in reduced emissions but in a net draw-down of the “legacy CO2” in the atmosphere. This technology may create new jobs in the American economy, mostly outside the urban commercial centers.

This SBIR project will develop a novel system that integrates CO2 direct air capture into a water electrolysis device so as to produce a stream of captured CO2 and green hydrogen (H2) from a single device with energy requirements not much higher than water electrolysis alone. The system relies on two primary innovations: 1) a water electrolysis process using a unique buffer solution and a novel reactor design that combines direct air contact with water electrolysis to simultaneously capture CO2 and produce H2 from water, and 2) a new hollow fiber membrane bioreactor that uses multiple layers of hydrogel-encapsulated organisms to convert the electrolysis reactor’s emissions into biogenic methane (also known as renewable natural gas or RNG), and eventually into more complex hydrocarbon molecules. The goal of this project is to optimize the performance of both the electrolysis reactor and the bioreactor in order to demonstrate an economically viable pathway for capturing ambient CO2 and “upcycling” it into RNG. While the initial upcycling target is RNG, the emissions from the electrolysis reactor are suitable for conversion into more complex hydrocarbons.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to explore a proof-of-concept system to produce biogenic methane, also known as Renewable Natural Gas (RNG) from atmospheric CO2, water, and renewable electricity without requiring digestion of biomass.

Renewable Natural Gas (RNG) is a promising pathway to reduce reliance on the combustion of fossil natural gas, which is contributing significantly to the global increase in atmospheric CO2 concentrations that is driving climate change. Because the carbon in RNG is drawn from existing CO2 in the atmosphere, combusting RNG recycles existing CO2 and does not create an overall increase in atmospheric CO2 concentrations. 

Presently, RNG is harvested from biogenic degradation of organic matter in landfills, dairies, and sewer treatment plants. These sources of RNG are inherently limited and cannot possibly scale to provide enough methane to supply the massive global infrastructure that relies on combustion of methane, especially as methane is an increasingly popular option for replacing diesel fuel in long-haul transportation. A system that can use renewable energy to produce RNG directly from atmospheric CO2 and water could produce unlimited quantities of RNG and could produce the RNG anywhere that water and renewable energy are available, thereby reducing the need to transport methane from sources to users.

After encountering and overcoming various obstacles, the project successfully demonstrated two key objectives:
1. A reactor that is able to produce a mixed gas stream consisting of 80% hydrogen from water (aka "green" hydrogen) with 20% carbon dioxide captured in an aqueous solution. This 80/20 ratio is the correct mix of gases to support the creation of RNG by hydrogenotrophic, methanogenic organisms.
2. A hollow fiber membrane bioreactor (HFMB) that demonstrated conversion of a mixed gas stream of hydrogen and carbon dioxide into RNG via a mixed population of hydrogenotrophic methanogens immobilized in hydrogel constructs within the HFMB.

Furthermore, the project produced a detailed techno-economic analysis for a combined system that is expected to be able to produce RNG from water, air, and renewable power at an economically competitive cost (net of current federal incentives) withiin the next few years based on the Department of Energy's predictions for the future cost of renewable energy and future (reduced) costs of electrochemical components used in this system.  


Last Modified: 12/07/2023
Modified by: Mike Robinson

Image
  • Making hydrocarbons from recycled atmospheric CO2
    Air2x Team

    Mike Robinson
    Air2x
